channel.title: Borrowing ags for mint
channel.description:
[s]Hai guise. So yeah, I have one mint cake (street price 4m+) and since I don't have junk at all (about 100k) I want to give it basically for free to someone who has an ags on one condition: you lend it to me for 24hrs and buy my junk worth of 160k = you get mint.[/s]
nevermind ;D i'll keep it and sell it away when i have enough junk

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

apparently you can also get them rarely by doing orders for the gnome restaurant minigame.

edit: oops, i might’ve bumped this a bit.

Read full topic

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

Protip: you can get them from the quest “Path of Glouphrie” IF you give this random guy a pair of “tangled toad legs”. One cake per one account (multiple accounts highly unlikely since the quest does need stats that take some time to level). That’s how I got mine ;), also, another reason why they’re high in demand is because most people who do that quest eat the cake not knowing what it is…

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

Davidude:

What I don’t understand is where these mint cakes come from? Can’t you get them from a quest or an npc or something? If not then they are effectively a rare anyway…

You get them from some gnome cooking game, but they’re kinda rare.

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:32, topic:324053”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=420456.msg3090833#msg3090833 date=1262892986]
That’s quite a risky business though. Of course the GE price will rise, but a market like that will almost certainly crash.
[/quote]

Right, we call that a market bubble. It’s only profitable for the original ‘big’ players, and the players that get in and out of the action quickly. Risk-Reward tradeoffs are a bitch but, if you play your cards right, it’s worth it.[/quote]The people who are buying the mint cakes make a nice profit too since what they’re really after is rares such as partyhats which people don’t sell just for cash.

Read full topic

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

I doubt that it’ll crash any time soon since it’s not like there are hundreds of thousands of mint cakes…

Read full topic

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

bootnecklad:

Thank you very much unlimitedorb! But how do these players dictate the effective prices?

The idea is for a group of very wealthy players to buy up all the mint cakes, and then agree upon a new price. A variety of factors can come into play. I’d venture a guess that their thought process was similar to this:

We want this to be an artificial rare item, but we want it to be affordable. We could always make them worth 100mil each, but would there be enough (worthless) longbows in circulation to translate from the official price to our price? Even if there were enough longbows, would it be affordable for the average well-off player?..

You have to keep in mind that the whole scheme is based on the idea of a ‘worthless’ item. Even if I gave you a ton of longbows, there’s pretty much nothing you could do with them by virtue of there being zero demand for them. If they aren’t careful, the demand for longbows will outweigh the supply and the bubble will burst early. They’re going to want to choose a price that will maximize their profits once they flood the market back up with mint cakes.

Read full topic

[quote=“bootnecklad, post:34, topic:324053”]Thank you very much unlimitedorb! But how do these players dictate the effective prices?[/quote]Whatever they want.

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @atrox atrox_
item.description:
@atrox wrote:

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:27, topic:324053”]If I understand this correctly, the end result of all of this is players controlling market liquidity and value.

It becomes easier to understand this if we talk in terms of extremes:

Player A - Suppose I’m trying to sell longbows via the Grand Exchange, but I’m unable to sell a single longbow because the demand for them is essentially zero. Even though the Grand Exchange sets the ‘official’ price at 1k [sic] per longbow, the effective price of a longbow is 0.

Now suppose that mint cakes are worth very little - 2k ea:
Player B - An extremely wealthy user comes along and buys up all the mint cakes in the game. The Grand Exchange reports the official price as 2k per mint cake, but the effective price of a mint cake is however much the wealthy user dictates.

Now, here’s where it gets interesting: Player B decides to sell one of his effectively priceless mint cakes for 4mil. The Grand Exchange still reports the ‘official’ price of a mint cake as 2k. How will he transfer the mint cake?

Player A and Player B discuss the situation with eachother and they come to a mutual agreement that, despite what the Grand Exchange says, a Longbow is worth 0k and a mint cake is worth 4mil. This is the key.

Player A offers 4mil to Player B.

Player B puts up a mint cake ‘officially’ worth 2k but effectively worth 4mil. He then add longbows that are ‘officially’ worth 4mil but effectively worth 0k. This makes up for the Grand Exchange price difference.

This is a dangerous precedent. This means that Player B, in this case, is more ‘official’ than the Grand Exchange itself. By putting the power to dictate prices into Player B’s hands, Player B has circumvented the reason for the Grand Exchange’s existence! This concept will eventually make Player B far more wealthy than before… what if he then decided to silently sell off all his mint cakes until the market is flooded, etc?

It follows that we can profit from this in the real world by setting up a consortium of players that dictate prices. They could even have a website that translates Grand Exchange prices to consortium prices. That would most likely generate alot of traffic. It seems as though this concept is still in its infant stages for RS. If someone decided to take the time to organize it and they had enough access to resources, they could profit big time off of this.[/quote]
much appreciated explanation, I didn’t have a fucking clue what was going on

Read full topic

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

That’s quite a risky business though. Of course the GE price will rise, but a market like that will almost certainly crash.

Right, we call that a market bubble. It’s only profitable for the original ‘big’ players, and the players that get in and out of the action quickly. Risk-Reward tradeoffs are a bitch but, if you play your cards right, it’s worth it.

Edit: This is basically equivalent to the Dot Com boom… and eventually we’re going to get to see the bust.

Read full topic

[quote=“eczema3, post:29, topic:324053”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=420456.msg3090824#msg3090824 date=1262892544]
So the transaction is 4mil for 1 mint cake and (at 1k ea) 3999 longbows. For the person selling the mint cake this transaction is attractive, but what does the buyer of the mint cake gain?
[/quote]
The mint cake, which was his original goal.[/quote]

Precisely… does this sound like anything familiar to you?

Answer: it’s an ‘artificial’ rare

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

If I understand this correctly, the end result of all of this is players controlling market liquidity and value.

It becomes easier to understand this if we talk in terms of extremes:

Player A - Suppose I’m trying to sell longbows via the Grand Exchange, but I’m unable to sell a single longbow because the demand for them is essentially zero. Even though the Grand Exchange sets the ‘official’ price at 1k [sic] per longbow, the effective price of a longbow is 0.

Now suppose that mint cakes are worth very little - 2k ea:
Player B - An extremely wealthy user comes along and buys up all the mint cakes in the game. The Grand Exchange reports the official price as 2k per mint cake, but the effective price of a mint cake is however much the wealthy user dictates.

Now, here’s where it gets interesting: Player B decides to sell one of his effectively priceless mint cakes for 4mil. The Grand Exchange still reports the ‘official’ price of a mint cake as 2k. How will he transfer the mint cake?

Player A and Player B discuss the situation with eachother and they come to a mutual agreement that, despite what the Grand Exchange says, a Longbow is worth 0k and a mint cake is worth 4mil. This is the key.

Player A offers 4mil to Player B.

Player B puts up a mint cake ‘officially’ worth 2k but effectively worth 4mil. He then add longbows that are ‘officially’ worth 4mil but effectively worth 0k. This makes up for the Grand Exchange price difference.

This is a dangerous precedent. This means that Player B, in this case, is more ‘official’ than the Grand Exchange itself. By putting the power to dictate prices into Player B’s hands, Player B has circumvented the reason for the Grand Exchange’s existence! This concept will eventually make Player B far more wealthy than before… what if he then decided to silently sell off all his mint cakes until the market is flooded, etc?

It follows that we can profit from this in the real world by setting up a consortium of players that dictate prices. They could even have a website that translates Grand Exchange prices to consortium prices. That would most likely generate alot of traffic. It seems as though this concept is still in its infant stages for RS. If someone decided to take the time to organize it and they had enough access to resources, they could profit big time off of this.

Read full topic

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

eczema3:

No, unstrung bows are mostly junk, apart from probably magic and yew. People tend to have a lot of unstrung willow long bows because it’s easy/fast fletching XP however the unstrung willow longbows don’t sell because nobody wants them.

The invisible hand of the market at work.

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:20, topic:324053”]Sorry if I have no idea what I’m talking about here, I haven’t played runescape for ages.

How exactly do you sell something the GE says is worth 25k for 4m anyway? Isn’t there a limit on that sort of thing?[/quote]

the person you are selling to offers up the amount of gold they want to pay and you offer the item they want as well as a number of “junk” items (such as unstrung willow/maple longbows) to even out the price difference.

Read full topic

item.title: Borrowing ags for mint
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:13, topic:324053”]You know a game is fucking stupid when there are player-designed trade mechanics such as Runescape’s ‘junk trading’.
I’m sure Jagex thought highly of themselves, being the first to go down the path of prohibition. Except some paths are seldom walked for a reason. Senator Conroy of Australia is doing the same by trying to forcefully make ISPs censor a secret list of URLs with what is ultimately a pretty loosely defined and easily expandable scope (Refused classification). Glad to see that Australia is getting into bed with North Korea, China, Burma and Iran.
/awareness raising attempt[/quote]
Why don’t you pour petrol on yourself and then light it while sitting in the lotus position?
